lines.text: All men should have daughters. It puts honey on their tongues.
I think you're a rogue, Sharpe. But you're on my side and one of my rogues. I don't want you dead.
[Hakeswill tries to rape Teresa]
Now open your legs ever so wide, and lie still as a dead'un!

What's to happen is, you will become proper soldiers. And draw tunics of the red bright light company of the South Essex, and you will hand in your precious rifle guns and draw proper muskets to go along with being proper dressed. Fit for soldiers at last!
[speaks into his hat]
Never thought you'd see it, did you, Mother?
[speaks to men]
You hate me, don't you? Well, I hate you.
[speaks into his hat again]
I do, I do, I do. I hates 'em!
[rounds on men]
Who said that? I heard that. Mad? Oh, no, I ain't mad. Not so's I don't know.
That rifle's loaded and rammed, Sergeant.
Sir?
Did you know, Sergeant?
Me, sir? No, sir, never, sir!
This yours, Sergeant?
No, sir. Not me, sir. Him, sir. Private 'Arper, sir!
Well how many more are loaded?
[puts rifles under Hakeswill's chin, pulls trigger, nothing happens]
Harris!
[throws him the rifle]
Cooper! Hagman! Perkins!
[threatens Hakeswill with Harper's volley gun]

They say you can't be killed, Sergeant Hakeswill. It is known. 'Come with me, my lads, for I cannot die. I'm going to live for ever, for they tried to hang me once but did... not... do it.' I could almost believe it. Except in the case of someone you tried to kill, Sergeant Hakeswill... and did... not... do it. I wonder who that might be, Sergeant. You're a dead man, Obadiah. BANG!
[while talking to Harper on sentry, Sharpe hands him a bottle of whiskey]
Here. St. Patrick's Day.
God save Ireland... you're a grand man.
[takes a pull]
For an Englishman.
[Harper, framed by Hakeswill for theft, is being flogged]
Ninety-three! Ninety-four! Ninety-five!
[Harper has spit out his gag and is grinning widely as the lash lands]
Ninety-six! Ninety-seven! Ninety-eight! Ninety-nine! One hundred! One hundred and all's done, sir!
[Harper is released. Still grinning, he starts to walk away]
Harper? Come back here.
Sir?
You're a brave man. I salute you for it.
[He tosses Harper a golden guinea. Harper catches it]
Thank you, sir. Thank you.
[He walks past Sharpe]
You all right?
[Harper's grin remains, but his voice quavers]

[whispering]
Jesus, it hurts like hell! I couldn't have taken much more.
Sgt. Hakeswill...
Permission to speak, sir!
[pause]
I've nothing to say, sir.
[drops voice]
Oh my word, what a surprise... Sharpie.
You are come to me?
Ever such a long way. I was despairing.
LEFT FACE!
[Hakeswill obeys automatically]
QUICK MARCH!
[Hakeswill walks forward until he is facing the wall. Sharpe grabs his head and mashes his face into the wall]
You lay a finger on any of my men, Sgt., and I'll bloody kill you.
Come smartly to attention now. Atten-SHUN!
[Obadiah stands up straight - and Sharpe belts him, hard. Hakeswill bows over]
Oh, now see, you don't move when an officer's talking to you. You should know that.
Unless you want to hit me, Obadiah?
Obadiah?
Dead, if you strike an officer, Obadiah. Dead. Oh... but he can't die. See his neck? They tried to hang him once, and it didn't kill him.
I can kill him.

In every battle some try. Look how he stands up. Never disobeys an officer, do you, Obadiah? Why, they love him! I would kill him here and now. Except I swore to do it in front of his victims, for all to see. It's been a long time coming. For he is *evil*, is Obadiah!

Obadiah, and a blackguardly officer called Morris, once beat a native Indian half to death, until I stopped them. They blamed me for it, and I was flogged. Watch him, Pat. He preys on the men. He'll snaffle kit, belts, frogs, haversacks, all entered or found lost by Obadiah, which leads to floggings unless he gets paid. Then wives. He beats men till their wives come to him, which I call rape. I've seen his like before. An evil man marching in a cloud of pipely. And because he kicks up salutes, obeys every officer, he's bombproof to all but us. We who come up from the ranks, we're smart to him.
We are that.
I'm a soldier, sir, not a bloody clerk! I fetch, I forage, and I take punishment drills! It's "yes sir, no sir, can I dig your latrine, sir?" and it's not bloody soldiering!
It *is* bloody soldiering! What the hell do you think soldiering is? Just because you've been allowed to swan about like a bloody pirate for years...!
Look, sir, when you fling us up against those walls, you'll be glad there's some pirates in there, and not just bloody clerks!

[about his soldiers]
God may damn them but I'm not inclined.

[Watching Cooper dig in a muddy trench]
Dig! You don't dig, you don't eat!

[Notices Sharpe]
Officer coming, Sarn't.
That ain't an officer I know Mr. Leftenant Sharpe
[holds his hands according to speech]
when me and Sharpe was like that! And that is me on top!

[Sarcastic]
Oh yes, oh yes...

[In Spanish]
My daughter is ill and all you can do is cry!
Come to show these lazy bastards how it's done, sir?
We're in! By the living God we're in!

[Gazing in horror at Badajoz]
It's time to go mad!

[Drunk]
Oh! He looks dead to me! Did you slice off his arm? Thought you did, thought I saw.
[Grins, and quickly runs off as fast as he can]
The men hate digging.
Wouldn't you?

[Awkward]
I have never dug.
